comments_since_last_sample.body:
Depends how often you play live and for how long and what kind of music.

Nasty sloppy punk? Keep the comfortable one especially if you’re gonna play a lot of hours and have it hanging from your shoulder, jumping around and what not.

If you need the better sounding and capable of multiple “tones” ranging from clean to hard, and you don’t gig too much, keep the Les comfortable.

But the best thing to do is sell both and get one that checks all the boxes.

Also never buy a guitar with anything less than an Alder body.

Still affordable but way better and brighter sounding than Basswood which most affordable guitars are made of.

keep both. I have an old squire I got for 40 bucks that I keep around because for some reason it's the easiest guitar to play. It's nice playing expensive guitars, but sometimes I don't care what it sounds like; sometimes I just want to play for the sake of playing, and effortlessly nailing every note while e.g. sweeping is worth more than some subtle tonal differences.
The one that sounds bad, why does it sound bad ? Is it an electric or an acoustic one ?
Comfort over sound, if you got good fingers and good rhythms you can make a tin can with fishing wire sound good.
I think you should sell both and get one that is both good sounding and comfortable.
Play the one that sounds better, but get a pro to set it up for you (shouldn't cost much).
If sweet riffs can be played on a hello kitty guitar, definitely go for comfort. With the right hands something terrible can sound great.
Think you just answered your own question there bud

Keep the Comfortable to play. 

Get rid of uncomfortable. If it’s uncomfortable, you’ll rarely play it, and your skills will decline… and then you’ll sound ever worse.
